entries.lesson: Simple direct field extension approach for Pydantic model enhancement
entries.context: Adding tutorial fields to existing Pydantic models for enhanced API responses
entries.details: When extending Pydantic models with new optional fields, direct field addition is more effective than complex nested model structures. Add Optional[str] fields directly to existing models (SearchResult, DocumentationItem) with appropriate default values (None). This approach maintains backward compatibility while enabling new functionality
entries.impact: Enables clean model extensions without breaking existing API consumers or complicating model hierarchy

entries.lesson: Ruff automatically formats Pydantic field definitions for consistency
entries.context: Code formatting and Pydantic model field organization
entries.details: Ruff's formatter automatically handles Pydantic field definition formatting, ensuring consistent spacing, alignment, and organization of field declarations. This includes proper handling of Optional types, default values, and field descriptions across model definitions
entries.impact: Maintains consistent code style without manual formatting effort, improves code readability and maintainability

entries.lesson: Tutorial content should be concise for token efficiency
entries.context: Implementing tutorial fields with content length optimization
entries.details: Tutorial content should be kept concise (15-30 tokens) to stay well under the 200 token limit per response. Focus on essential usage patterns, brief code examples, and key concepts rather than comprehensive documentation. This ensures tutorial additions enhance responses without significantly impacting token budgets
entries.impact: Provides valuable tutorial information while maintaining efficient token usage and response performance

entries.lesson: Test both presence and content of tutorial fields for comprehensive validation
entries.context: Testing strategies for optional Pydantic model fields
entries.details: When testing tutorial field implementations, verify both field presence (is not None) and content quality. Test scenarios should include: 1) Fields are populated when tutorial content is available, 2) Content matches expected format and length constraints, 3) Fields remain None when no tutorial content exists, 4) Backward compatibility with clients not expecting tutorial fields
entries.impact: Ensures tutorial field implementation works correctly across all use cases while maintaining backward compatibility

entries.lesson: FastAPI/MCP automatically serializes optional None fields maintaining backward compatibility
entries.context: API serialization behavior with optional Pydantic fields
entries.details: FastAPI and MCP automatically handle serialization of optional fields with None values, maintaining backward compatibility with existing API consumers. Fields with None values are properly serialized in JSON responses, allowing clients to safely ignore fields they don't recognize while new clients can utilize the additional information
entries.impact: Enables safe API extension without breaking existing integrations, supports gradual feature rollout

serializationBehavior.noneValues: Serialized as null in JSON responses
serializationBehavior.backwardCompatibility: Existing clients can safely ignore new fields
serializationBehavior.forwardCompatibility: New clients can utilize additional tutorial information

entries.lesson: Pydantic model extension patterns for similar enhancements
entries.context: Guidelines for future Pydantic model enhancements based on tutorial field implementation
entries.details: Future Pydantic model extensions should follow established patterns: 1) Use Optional[Type] with None defaults for backward compatibility, 2) Add fields directly to existing models rather than creating nested structures, 3) Consider token efficiency for content fields, 4) Test both field presence and content validation, 5) Leverage Ruff for consistent formatting, 6) Verify serialization behavior maintains API compatibility
entries.impact: Provides reusable patterns for future model enhancements, ensuring consistency and reliability across API evolution
implementationChecklist: Add fields directly to existing models
Consider content length and token efficiency
Test field presence and content validation

cicdBestPractices.description: Best practices for CI/CD pipeline implementation and deployment

entries.description: Always use 'uv run' pattern instead of direct executable calls to ensure Windows compatibility
entries.rationale: Direct executable calls can fail on Windows due to path resolution issues, while 'uv run' provides consistent cross-platform behavior
entries.implementation: Replace direct calls like 'docsrs-mcp' with 'uv run docsrs-mcp' in all CI workflows

entries.description: Use UV_PUBLISH_TOKEN environment variable for PyPI publishing authentication
entries.rationale: UV_PUBLISH_TOKEN is the correct environment variable for PyPI authentication, not UV_PUBLISH_PASSWORD
entries.implementation: Set UV_PUBLISH_TOKEN in CI secrets and use in publishing workflows

entries.description: Use nohup with PID capture for testing background servers in CI environments
entries.rationale: Prevents CI runners from hanging on background processes and enables proper cleanup
entries.implementation: Pattern: 'SERVER_PID=$(nohup uv run server > server.log 2>&1 & echo $!)' followed by 'kill $SERVER_PID'

entries.description: Pin UV versions across all CI jobs to prevent cache deserialization errors
entries.rationale: Different UV versions can cause cache corruption and build failures due to incompatible cache formats
entries.implementation: Use specific UV version in CI workflows and clear cache when upgrading versions

entries.description: Use 'uv build --no-sources' for PyPI publishing to ensure package compatibility
entries.rationale: Including source files can cause PyPI build failures and package incompatibility issues
entries.implementation: Add --no-sources flag to build commands in publishing workflows

entries.description: Implement different cache strategies for GitHub-hosted vs self-hosted runners
entries.rationale: Self-hosted runners have persistent storage and different performance characteristics than GitHub-hosted runners
entries.implementation: Use local disk cache for self-hosted runners, GitHub Actions cache for hosted runners

bestPractices.description: Recommended practices and patterns for development

entries.description: Separate example embeddings from document embeddings for better semantic search precision
entries.implementation: Use dedicated tables (example_embeddings, vec_example_embeddings) with content hashing for deduplication. Format examples with context for better embedding quality.
benefits: Better search performance with dedicated indexes
caveats: First search is slower due to model loading

entries.issue: Circular import between ingest.py and popular_crates.py
entries.solution: Use lazy import inside function to avoid circular dependency. Import get_popular_manager inside evict_cache_if_needed() instead of at module level.
entries.lesson: When modules have bidirectional dependencies, use lazy imports inside functions rather than module-level imports to break the cycle.
entries.context: Priority-aware cache eviction feature implementation

testing.description: Testing patterns and solutions for complex scenarios

entries.issue: Mocking imported functions that are lazily imported
entries.solution: When a function is imported inside another function (lazy import), patch it at its original module location, not where it's imported. Example: patch 'module.function' not 'importing_module.function'
entries.lesson: Always patch at the source module, not at the import location, especially for lazy imports.
entries.context: Testing priority-aware cache eviction with lazy imports
